subject: RE: [junit] Message texts
msgSnippet: So you d write assertTrue( someBoolean is not true! , someBoolean); Or as another example assertEquals( The answer isn t the same! , expected, actual); Thanks
messageBody:
So you'd write
assertTrue("someBoolean is not true!", someBoolean);

Or as another example
assertEquals("The answer isn't the same!", expected, actual);


Thanks
--DP

-----Original Message-----
From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
Sent: Wednesday, July 21, 2004 12:42 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Message texts


David Plass wrote:

> What's the consensus on the style of message texts?
> E.g.,
> assertTrue("Should be true", someBoolean);
> or
> assertTrue("Is true", someBoolean);
> or
> assertTrue(someBoolean); // !
>
> I usually use the former; what is typically done "in the real world"?

I prefer the text to describe the potential problem -- what might cause
the assertion to fail. Example:

try {
Person.create("Joe", null);
fail("Created a Person without a last name?!");
}
catch (IllegalArgumentException expected) {}

In that case, the closest would be #1 on your list, although I
frequently do #3. (Line numbers are enough.)
--
